Issues.Title: SplashScreen form not shown unless Startup Form set to Sub Main
Issues.Body:
<!-- Read https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/blob/master/docs/issue-guide.md -->

* .NET Core Version: 
Microsoft.WindowsDesktop.App 5.0.0

* Have you experienced this same bug with .NET Framework?: 
No

**Problem description:**

In Framework SplashScreen is shown if one is defined in project file and Project Startup object is set to Form1. In Core the splash screen is only shown if Startup object is set to Sub Main

**Expected behavior:**
SplashScreen is shown if Startup object is set to Form1

**Minimal repro:**
https://github.com/paul1956/WinForms5VBSample
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "SplashScreen form not shown unless Startup Form set to Sub Main" (#4279)

Issues.Title: Failed to create .NET Core VB project by using CML
Issues.Body:
* More info:
This is a regression issue, can't reproduce on .NET SDK 6.0.100-alpha.1.20573.16

* .NET Core Version: 
.NET 6.0.100-alpha.1.20574.5 build

* Have you experienced this same bug with .NET Framework?: 
No

**Minimal repro:**
1. Installed the latest .NET SDK 6.0 from https://github.com/dotnet/installer.
2. Create a .NET Core winforms VB project by using CML: **dotnet new winforms -lang VB**

**Expected behavior:**
The .NET Core winforms VB project created successfully.
![Expect](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/38325459/100178455-d97fa180-2f0e-11eb-865c-4ded74672514.PNG)

**Actual behavior:**
Failed to create .NET Core VB project by using CML
![VBIssue](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/38325459/100178388-b9e87900-2f0e-11eb-808d-b9bdc97dff97.gif)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Failed to create .NET Core VB project by using CML" (#4278)

Issues.Title: ActiveX support in .Net 5 Windows Forms designer?
Issues.Body:
* .NET Core Version: 
.Net 5

* Have you experienced this same bug with .NET Framework?: 
No

**Problem description:**

The Windows Forms designer for .Net 5 appears to be brain-dead with regard to ActiveX controls.

I have not succeeded in getting any ActiveX controls working in the Toolbox. The 'Choose items' dialog says:

_'The following controls were successfully added to the toolbox but are not enabled in the active designer. .... Make sure the controls to add are compatible with the current designer and .Net Framework version.'_

Well, the controls are all perfectly compatible with .Net 5 and work fine if they are manually included in the form design, so I have to conclude that the current version of the designer simply doesn't do ActiveX.

Please confirm this, and indicate whether there is likely to be full support for ActiveX controls any time soon.

Or tell me what I'm doing wrong!...

**Expected behavior:**

The chosen ActiveX control should appear in the Toolbox and create the control properly when applied to the form.

**Minimal repro:**

For example:

1. Create new .Net 5 C# Windows Forms app in Visual Studio 2019 v16.8 or later
2. Right-click on a category header in the Toolbox and Select 'Choose Items...' .
3. On the 'COM Components' tab of the 'Choose Toolbox Items 'dialog, set the checkbox for a control (for example the Calendar Control 8.0 is conveniently near the top of the list).
4. A new window appears with the error message shown in the description above. The control is not visible in the Toolbox.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "ActiveX support in .Net 5 Windows Forms designer?" (#4272)

Issues.Title: The 'Windows Forms Remote Designer Hosting Package' package did not load correctly.
Issues.Body:
<!-- Read https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/blob/master/docs/issue-guide.md -->

* .NET Core Version: 
Net5.0

* Have you experienced this same bug with .NET Framework?: 
No

Creating a new project gives me this error:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1185948/100077821-18e0bc00-2e43-11eb-9e79-fc0aa17943b5.png)

Activity log:

```
<entry>
    <record>2302</record>
    <time>2020/11/24 09:58:18.678</time>
    <type>Information</type>
    <source>VisualStudio</source>
    <description>Begin package load [Windows Forms Remote Designer Hosting Package]</description>
    <guid>{C78CA057-CC29-421F-AD6D-3B0943DEBDFC}</guid>
  </entry>
  <entry>
    <record>2303</record>
    <time>2020/11/24 09:58:18.679</time>
    <type>Error</type>
    <source>VisualStudio</source>
    <description>CreateInstance failed for package [Windows Forms Remote Designer Hosting Package]Source: 'mscorlib' Description: Could not load type 'Microsoft.VisualStudio.Design.VSDesignPackage' from assembly 'Microsoft.VisualStudio.WinForms.Package, Version=0.3.2.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=31bf3856ad364e35'.
System.TypeLoadException: Could not load type 'Microsoft.VisualStudio.Design.VSDesignPackage' from assembly 'Microsoft.VisualStudio.WinForms.Package, Version=0.3.2.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=31bf3856ad364e35'.
   at System.Reflection.RuntimeAssembly.GetType(RuntimeAssembly assembly, String name, Boolean throwOnError, Boolean ignoreCase, ObjectHandleOnStack type)
   at System.Reflection.RuntimeAssembly.GetType(String name, Boolean throwOnError, Boolean ignoreCase)
   at System.Activator.CreateInstanceFromInternal(String assemblyFile, String typeName, Boolean ignoreCase, BindingFlags bindingAttr, Binder binder, Object[] args, CultureInfo culture, Object[] activationAttributes, Evidence securityInfo)
   at System.AppDomain.CreateInstanceFrom(String assemblyFile, String typeName)</description>
    <guid>{C78CA057-CC29-421F-AD6D-3B0943DEBDFC}</guid>
    <hr>80004005 - E_FAIL</hr>
    <errorinfo></errorinfo>
  </entry>

```
Restarting VS does not help.

When trying to open Form1 designer, I get this error:
"The designer could not  be shown for this file because none of the classes within it can be designed.  The designer inspected the following classes in the file: Form1 --- The base  class 'System.Windows.Forms.Form' could not be loaded. Ensure the assembly has  been referenced and that all projects have been built. |   | The designer could not  be shown for this file because none of the classes within it can be designed.  The designer inspected the following classes in the file: Form1 --- The base  class 'System.Windows.Forms.Form' could not be loaded. Ensure the assembly has  been referenced and that all projects have been built."

**Expected behavior:**


**Minimal repro:**
Create new project and I got the error right away...
![2020-11-24_10-58-39](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1185948/100078809-35c9bf00-2e44-11eb-8dbd-7310c0cf084e.gif)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "The 'Windows Forms Remote Designer Hosting Package' package did not load correctly." (#4269)

Issues.Title: [Accessibility]HighContrast: ToolStripButtons in PropertyGrid should have obvious distinct between focused and checked status
Issues.Body:
* .NET Core Version: 
6.0.100-aipha.1.20573.16

* Have you experienced this same bug with .NET Framework?: 
Yes

**Minimal repro:**
1. Extract following attached app and open it in VS
[WinFormsApp30.zip](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/files/5588567/WinFormsApp30.zip)
2. Set Windows as HighContrast modes: HC Black/White/#1/#2
3. Build and run the project.
4. Press "Right/Left" arrow to focus on "Categorized", "Alphabetical" and " Property Pages" toolStripbuttons.

**Actual behavior:**
ToolStripButtons in PropertyGrid have no obvious distinct between focused and checked status in HC themes
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/26474449/100072081-c5886100-2e76-11eb-92f5-390882b13f65.png)

**Expected behavior:**
Make focused and checked tool strip buttons look more distinct in HC themes
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "[Accessibility]HighContrast: ToolStripButtons in PropertyGrid should have obvious distinct between focused and checked status" (#4268)

Issues.Title: RichTextBox Monospace Font Rendering is Broken
Issues.Body:
* .NET Core Version: 
.Net 6.0.100-alpha.1.20568.7 from master branch

* Have you experienced this same bug with .NET Framework?: 
Yes

**More Info:**

1. This issue also can reproduce on .Net Core 3.1.
2. This is a regression issue, it can reproduce from .Net framework 4.7 to 4.8, but cannot reproduce on .Net Framework 4.6.2. In addition, from .Net framework 4.7 to 4.8, there is a workaround: add the quirk to the App.config file.
 ```
 <runtime>
	<AppContextSwitchOverrides value="Switch.System.Windows.Forms.DoNotLoadLatestRichEditControl=true"/>
</runtime>
 ```

**Minimal repro:**

1. Extract the [RichTextBoxDemo.zip](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/files/5572035/RichTextBoxDemo.zip) and open it in VS.
2. Build and run this application.
3. Observe the length of Text in RichTextBox.

**Expected behavior:**
The Text of the same length in the RichTextBox should be consistent.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/45864649/99774896-5e527000-2b49-11eb-9b6a-ed9b99cb6787.png)

**Actual behavior:**
The text of the same length in the RichTextBox is not consistent.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/45864649/99774721-277c5a00-2b49-11eb-9b26-a58cafa78498.png)
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/45864649/99774827-44b12880-2b49-11eb-9f88-36987a397498.png)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "RichTextBox Monospace Font Rendering is Broken" (#4260)

Issues.Title: Windows Forms App (.NET) .NET5.0 SkiaSharp throws Attempted to read or write protected memory
Issues.Body:
# Issue
I have built a Windows Forms App (.NET) using .NET 5.0 rc2 and SkiaSharp. It is throwing the error: “Message=Attempted to read or write protected memory. This is often an indication that other memory is corrupt.”

# General

I have put my reproducible solution on GitHub at: https://github.com/CBrauer/TestSkia
I hope you guys can use this complete solution to fix the error.

# Environment
Microsoft Windows 10 Enterprise, version 10.0,19042 Build 19042
Microsoft Visual Studio Professional 2019 Preview Version 16.9.0 Preview 1.0
.NET 5.0 rc2

Charles
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Windows Forms App (.NET) .NET5.0 SkiaSharp throws Attempted to read or write protected memory" (#4261)

Issues.Title: Enable post-build signing
Issues.Body:
Enables post build signing. This repo will discontinue signing in-build and instead the entire product will sign all at once in the staging pipelines.

Issues.Title: Sited `ImageList` attached to `ListView` detached twice
Issues.Body:
<!-- Read https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/blob/master/docs/issue-guide.md -->

* .NET Core Version: 
.NET 5.0 RTM, .NET 6.0

* Have you experienced this same bug with .NET Framework?: 
No

**Problem description:**

A sited `ImageList` (i.e. added to an `IContainer`) 
```cs
imageList = new System.Windows.Forms.ImageList(this.components);
```

that is shared across several properties (e.g. `LargeImageList` and `SmallImageList`) upon the container disposal will be detached trice tripping on an assert (on the 2nd and 3rd re-entries):
https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/blob/26ee7b5fea05516d1caa83b94995c54115c148a1/src/System.Windows.Forms/src/System/Windows/Forms/ListView.cs#L2978-L2988

The first time `DetachImageList` is called, the `sender` will be equal to both `_imageListSmall` and `_imageListLarge`, on the 2nd and the 3rd entries the `sender` won't be equal to any of those since they were nulled out on the 1st call, but the instance of the imagelist would be the same as the one that was bound to those properties.

This doesn't happen if an imagelist is not sited, i.e. 
```cs
imageList = new System.Windows.Forms.ImageList();
```

When the imagelist is not sited, whenever the form is closed, the listivew is getting disposed, and it detaches event handlers before unsetting imagelists:
```
>	System.Windows.Forms.dll!System.Windows.Forms.ListView.DetachSmallImageListListHandlers() Line 3042	C#	Symbols loaded.
 	System.Windows.Forms.dll!System.Windows.Forms.ListView.Dispose(bool disposing = true) Line 3073	C#	Symbols loaded.
 	System.ComponentModel.Primitives.dll!System.ComponentModel.Component.Dispose() Line 74	C#	Symbols loaded.
 	System.Windows.Forms.dll!System.Windows.Forms.Control.Dispose(bool disposing = true) Line 5167	C#	Symbols loaded.
 	System.Windows.Forms.dll!System.Windows.Forms.ContainerControl.Dispose(bool disposing = true) Line 607	C#	Symbols loaded.
 	System.Windows.Forms.dll!System.Windows.Forms.Form.Dispose(bool disposing = true) Line 3309	C#	Symbols loaded.
 	ListViewRepro.dll!ListViewRepro.MainForm.Dispose(bool disposing = true) Line 20	C#	Symbols loaded.
```

However in "sited" case, the container will invoke the dispose sequence before we dispose the imagelist, and thus detach imagelist handlers:
```
>	System.Windows.Forms.dll!System.Windows.Forms.ListView.DetachImageList(object sender = {System.Windows.Forms.ImageList}, System.EventArgs e = {System.EventArgs}) Line 2984	C#	Symbols loaded.
 	System.ComponentModel.Primitives.dll!System.ComponentModel.Component.Dispose(bool disposing)	Unknown	No symbols loaded.
 	System.Windows.Forms.dll!System.Windows.Forms.ImageList.Dispose(bool disposing = true) Line 538	C#	Symbols loaded.
 	System.ComponentModel.Primitives.dll!System.ComponentModel.Component.Dispose()	Unknown	No symbols loaded.
 	System.ComponentModel.TypeConverter.dll!System.ComponentModel.Container.Dispose(bool disposing)	Unknown	No symbols loaded.
 	System.ComponentModel.TypeConverter.dll!System.ComponentModel.Container.Dispose()	Unknown	No symbols loaded.
 	ListViewRepro.dll!ListViewRepro.MainForm.Dispose(bool disposing = true) Line 18	C#	Symbols loaded.
```

**Expected behavior:**


**Minimal repro:**

```cs
    public partial class MainForm : Form
    {
        private System.ComponentModel.IContainer components = null;
        private System.Windows.Forms.ListView listView;

        public MainForm()
        {
            InitializeComponent();
        }

        protected override void Dispose(bool disposing)
        {
            if (disposing && (components != null))
            {
                components.Dispose();
            }
            base.Dispose(disposing);
        }

        private void InitializeComponent()
        {
            this.components = new System.ComponentModel.Container();
            System.Windows.Forms.ImageList imageList;
            this.listView = new System.Windows.Forms.ListView();
            imageList = new System.Windows.Forms.ImageList(this.components);
            this.SuspendLayout();
            // 
            // imageList
            // 
            imageList.ColorDepth = System.Windows.Forms.ColorDepth.Depth32Bit;
            imageList.ImageSize = new System.Drawing.Size(16, 16);
            imageList.TransparentColor = System.Drawing.Color.Transparent;
            // 
            // listView
            // 
            this.listView.Dock = System.Windows.Forms.DockStyle.Fill;
            this.listView.HideSelection = false;
            this.listView.Location = new System.Drawing.Point(0, 0);
            this.listView.Name = "listView";
            this.listView.Size = new System.Drawing.Size(686, 390);
            this.listView.LargeImageList = imageList;				// 
            this.listView.SmallImageList = imageList;				// sharing is important!
            this.listView.TabIndex = 0;
            this.listView.UseCompatibleStateImageBehavior = false;
            // 
            // MainForm
            // 
            this.AutoScaleDimensions = new System.Drawing.SizeF(6F, 13F);
            this.AutoScaleMode = System.Windows.Forms.AutoScaleMode.Font;
            this.ClientSize = new System.Drawing.Size(686, 390);
            this.Controls.Add(this.listView);
            this.Name = "MainForm";
            this.Text = "MainForm";
            this.ResumeLayout(false);

        }
    }
```
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Sited `ImageList` attached to `ListView` detached twice" (#4265)

Issues.Title: ListView does not display icons for items added after the form has been loaded
Issues.Body:
* .NET Core Version: 5.0.100

* Have you experienced this same bug with .NET Framework?: No

**Problem description:**

ListView renders items added after the form has been loaded without their icons. This happens regardless of the configured view.

The provided repro adds 50 items in the constructor, Form.Load handler and Form.Shown handler respectively. As you can see, only the first 50 items are displayed with icons, although all items are generated and added by the same function.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/13226155/99891805-3e689c80-2c6e-11eb-96fa-7302c6af9121.png)

**Expected behavior:**
The same project built for .NET Core 3.1:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/13226155/99891844-a7e8ab00-2c6e-11eb-9c3c-3e848842fd15.png)


**Minimal repro:**
https://github.com/dhrdlicka/ListViewRepro
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "ListView does not display icons for items added after the form has been loaded" (#4263)

Issues.Title: ListView.Items.Add throws ExecutionEngineException with custom ListViewItemSorter
Issues.Body:
* .NET Core Version: 5.0.100

* Have you experienced this same bug with .NET Framework?: No

**Problem description:**

ListView.Items.Add throws ExecutionEngineException upon reaching a certain number of items in the ListView when ListView.ListViewItemSorter is used to sort the items.

The exact number might vary on the specific use case and machine setup. The repro linked below crashes on my machine after ~130 added items, although I have observed numbers as low as 16 in a project of mine.

This didn't happen in .NET Core 3.1.

Stack trace:
```
Process terminated. A callback was made on a garbage collected delegate of type 'System.Windows.Forms.Primitives!System.Windows.Forms.NativeMethods+ListViewCompareCallback::Invoke'.
Repeat 2 times:
--------------------------------
   at Interop+User32.CallWindowProcW(IntPtr, IntPtr, WM, IntPtr, IntPtr)
--------------------------------
   at System.Windows.Forms.NativeWindow.DefWndProc(System.Windows.Forms.Message ByRef)
   at System.Windows.Forms.Control.WndProc(System.Windows.Forms.Message ByRef)
   at System.Windows.Forms.ListView.WndProc(System.Windows.Forms.Message ByRef)
   at System.Windows.Forms.Control+ControlNativeWindow.WndProc(System.Windows.Forms.Message ByRef)
   at System.Windows.Forms.NativeWindow.Callback(IntPtr, WM, IntPtr, IntPtr)
   at Interop+User32.SendMessageW(IntPtr, WM, IntPtr, IntPtr)
   at Interop+User32.SendMessageW(IntPtr, WM, IntPtr, IntPtr)
   at System.Windows.Forms.ListView.Sort()
   at System.Windows.Forms.ListView.InsertItems(Int32, System.Windows.Forms.ListViewItem[], Boolean)
   at System.Windows.Forms.ListView+ListViewNativeItemCollection.Add(System.Windows.Forms.ListViewItem)
   at System.Windows.Forms.ListView+ListViewItemCollection.Add(System.Windows.Forms.ListViewItem)
   at ListViewRepro.MainForm.AddFruit()
   at ListViewRepro.MainForm.MainForm_Shown(System.Object, System.EventArgs)
   at System.Windows.Forms.Form.OnShown(System.EventArgs)
   at System.Windows.Forms.Form.CallShownEvent()
   at System.Windows.Forms.Control.InvokeMarshaledCallbackDo(ThreadMethodEntry)
   at System.Windows.Forms.Control.InvokeMarshaledCallbackHelper(System.Object)
   at System.Threading.ExecutionContext.RunInternal(System.Threading.ExecutionContext, System.Threading.ContextCallback, System.Object)
   at System.Threading.ExecutionContext.Run(System.Threading.ExecutionContext, System.Threading.ContextCallback, System.Object)
   at System.Windows.Forms.Control.InvokeMarshaledCallback(ThreadMethodEntry)
   at System.Windows.Forms.Control.InvokeMarshaledCallbacks()
   at System.Windows.Forms.Control.WndProc(System.Windows.Forms.Message ByRef)
   at System.Windows.Forms.ScrollableControl.WndProc(System.Windows.Forms.Message ByRef)
   at System.Windows.Forms.Form.WndProc(System.Windows.Forms.Message ByRef)
   at System.Windows.Forms.Control+ControlNativeWindow.WndProc(System.Windows.Forms.Message ByRef)
   at System.Windows.Forms.NativeWindow.Callback(IntPtr, WM, IntPtr, IntPtr)
   at Interop+User32.DispatchMessageW(MSG ByRef)
   at Interop+User32.DispatchMessageW(MSG ByRef)
   at System.Windows.Forms.Application+ComponentManager.Interop.Mso.IMsoComponentManager.FPushMessageLoop(UIntPtr, msoloop, Void*)
   at System.Windows.Forms.Application+ThreadContext.RunMessageLoopInner(msoloop, System.Windows.Forms.ApplicationContext)
   at System.Windows.Forms.Application+ThreadContext.RunMessageLoop(msoloop, System.Windows.Forms.ApplicationContext)
   at System.Windows.Forms.Application.Run(System.Windows.Forms.Form)
   at ListViewRepro.Program.Main()
```

**Expected behavior:**
ListView.Add does not throw ExecutionEngineException.

**Minimal repro:**
https://github.com/dhrdlicka/ListViewRepro (The LVIS assignment is commented out in the MainForm constructor as the same project serves as repro on another issue as well)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "ListView.Items.Add throws ExecutionEngineException with custom ListViewItemSorter" (#4264)

Issues.Title: **NO-MERGE** Proof of concept for running unit tests through helix
Issues.Body:
Fixes #3140 
Fixes https://github.com/dotnet/winforms-designer/issues/1732

This work is tracked by https://github.com/dotnet/winforms-designer/issues/1732 in the winforms-designer repo.

This task is mostly done, but there are still some remaining tasks:

1. Scaling to other OS's if we choose to (this is easy, just add to the `_HelixTargetQueues` variables in the yaml.
1. Fixing the few unit tests that are failing
1. Fixing the integration tests.
   * This one is the biggest task, as it's not as simple as unit tests. See https://github.com/dotnet/winforms-designer/issues/1732#issuecomment-729954799 for details.

###### Microsoft Reviewers: [Open in CodeFlow](http://wpcp.azurewebsites.net/CodeFlowProtocolProxy2.php?pullrequest=https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/pull/4259)

Issues.Title: Survey: Repo contribution experience, Fall 2020
Issues.Body:
We normally focus on how to improve the product, but we’re also turning our focus to improving the open source project. Periodically we are running a survey to collect feedback on your experience working with our repos. We did one back in May, and as its been about 6 months, its about time for another. We’ve created a survey to better understand your individual experience of participating and contributing in this project.

We would appreciate your feedback so we can work to address shortcomings and missed opportunities. If you don’t supply contact details, then responses will be anonymous.

[Survey](https://www.surveymonkey.com/r/92RLF7R?Source=dotnet/winforms)

Thank you for your time!
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Survey: Repo contribution experience, Fall 2020" (#4255)

Issues.Title: Adding a part of the `DataGridView` test app to check DGV in Virtual mode
Issues.Body:
Just adding a UI test case to have an additional example

## Proposed changes

- Add a DataGridView in Virtual mode with some data to an existing test app
- Rename the UI test app

<!-- We are in TELL-MODE the following section must be completed -->

## Customer Impact

- Users can see an example of how to implement and set up a `DataGridView` in Virtual mode in their applications

## Regression? 

- No

## Risk

- Minimal

<!-- end TELL-MODE -->


## Screenshots <!-- Remove this section if PR does not change UI -->
- Now the test app looks like that:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/49272759/99508646-e263f680-2995-11eb-85d2-c66e05114c7c.png)



## Test methodology <!-- How did you ensure quality? -->

- UI testing

## Test environment(s) <!-- Remove any that don't apply -->

- Microsoft Windows [Version 10.0.19042.630]
- .NET SDK Version:   6.0.100-alpha.1.20554.10


<!-- Mention language, UI scaling, or anything else that might be relevant -->
